thread.title: This Exeter High Street store is about to close for good

author: Alex Richards
title: This Exeter High Street store is about to close for good
text:
This Exeter High Street store is about to close for good New Look Men is one of the casualties of the High Street crunch Share Alex Richards Deputy News Editor 16:43, 25 SEP 2018 Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
A fashion shop in Exeter's Princesshay Shopping Centre is about to close, and there's bargains galore.
New Look Men is downsizing its stock and returning to its parent New Look store nearby.
The existing store will cease trading for good tomorrow afternoon (Wednesday, September 26).
A large amount of existing stock is being sold at rock bottom prices ahead of the closure. New Look Men closure
Items on the sale racks include jeans, shirts, blazers and summerwear. But why is it closing?
Earlier this year New Look confirmed plans to close 60 stores in the UK including three in Devon.
Nationally, it means the loss of up to 1,000 jobs. Read More All the shops and restaurants we have lost in Exeter so far this year
In a statement in June, New Look said it had secured a new restructuring plan that will see 60 stores axed and rents reduced in a further 393 branches.
Alistair McGeorge, of New Look, said at the time of the announcement in March: "Given our challenged trading performance and over-rented UK store estate, New Look chairman Alistair McGeorge said: "In order to help restore long-term profitability, it is clear we need to reduce our fixed cost base. New Look Men closure
"We are therefore pleased to have gained the support of our creditors to address our over-rented store estate. Launching a CVA has been a tough decision and our priority remains keeping all potentially affected colleagues informed during this difficult time.
"The CVA is one of a number of necessary actions we are taking to get the company back on track.
"In addition to implementing other cost-saving initiatives, we are already focusing on driving future full price sales by realigning our pricing to offer significantly better value, adding flexibility to our buying model, and improving our speed to market."
Daniel Butters, at Deloitte, the consultancy firm managing the CVA, said: “The retail trading environment in the UK remains extremely challenging, driven by weaker consumer confidence, the implications of Brexit and competition from online channels. The new Look in Torquay is one of the town's biggest shops (Image: Geograph)
“New Look is an iconic brand on the high street and the CVA will provide a stable platform upon which Management’s turnaround plan can be delivered.
“It is important to stress that no stores will close on day one, and employees, suppliers and business rates will continue to be paid on time and in full." Read More
